description: The server has received the request headers and the client should proceed to send the request body
Possible_Threat: May be used to probe server behavior or perform reconnaissance on how a server handles requests

description: The requester has asked the server to switch protocols
Possible_Threat: Upgrading the connectionsu ch as to WebSockets could be exploited to bypass certain security checks or firewall rules

description: Used with the Link header to allow the browser to start preloading resources while the server prepares a response
Possible_Threat: Attackers could use the 103 status code to pre-load malicious resources (e.g. JavaScript or CSS) on a phishing page. This technique could make the phishing page appear more legitimate by pre-loading content that matches the look and feel of a legitimate site.

description: The request is OK (this is the standard response for successful HTTP requests)
Possible_Threat: Although a success code if seen in unexpected contexts (e.g. following unusual access patterns) it may indicate successful exploitation or access to sensitive information.

description: The request has been fulfilled and a new resource is created
The request has been accepted for processing but the processing has not been completed
Possible_Threat: If an application accepts a request and returns a 202 status code but defers the actual processing; there is a risk that the request could be tampered with or manipulated before the processing completes.

description: The request has been successfully processed but is returning information that may be from another source
Possible_Threat: A malicious proxy could modify the content of the response before it reaches the client potentially injecting malicious code / altering content / or stripping out important information such as security headers.

description: The request has been successfully processed but is not returning any content
Possible_Threat: Could be used in a covert channel as no content is returned which might be an attempt to communicate with a compromised system without leaving a large footprint

description: The request has been successfully processed but is not returning any content and requires that the requester reset the document view
Possible_Threat: A phishing attack could potentially abuse the 205 Reset Content status to reset a form after a user submits sensitive information; prompting them to re-enter the data. The attacker could then capture this information without the user realizing it was already submitted.

description: The server is delivering only part of the resource due to a range header sent by the client
Possible_Threat: Range requests can be abused in DDoS attacks; where attackers flood a server with multiple partial content requests overwhelming the server’s resources.

description: A link list. The user can select a link and go to that location. Maximum five addresses
Possible_Threat: Attackers could use 301 redirects to hijack legitimate traffic and send it to malicious sites

description: The requested page has moved to a new URL
Possible_Threat: could be used for phishing by redirecting users to malicious sites. Persistent redirections might indicate an attempt to manipulate traffic flows.

description: The requested page has moved temporarily to a new URL
Possible_Threat: An attacker could use a 302 redirect to temporarily redirect users from a legitimate site to a malicious one where phishing pages are hosted. This can be used to steal credentials / personal information or payment details.

description: The requested page can be found under a different URL
Possible_Threat: An attacker may exploit open redirect vulnerabilities where a 303 status code redirects users to a malicious site.

description: Indicates the requested page has not been modified since last requested
The requested page has moved temporarily to a new URL
Possible_Threat: similar to 301/302 but with method preservation. These could be used to redirect legitimate traffic to malicious destinations.

description: The requested page has moved permanently to a new URL
Possible_Threat: Attackers could use 308 redirects to direct users from a legitimate-looking URL to a malicious one. This tactic can be used in phishing campaigns to deceive users into believing they are accessing a legitimate site.

description: The request cannot be fulfilled due to bad syntax
Possible_Threat: May indicate malformed requests possibly from automated tools or scanners probing for weaknesses.

description: The request was a legal request but the server is refusing to respond to it. For use when authentication is possible but has failed or not yet been provided
Possible_Threat: Repeated 401 errors might indicate brute force attempts or credential stuffing attacks.

description: Reserved for future use
Possible_Threat: An attacker could use the 402 Payment Required status in phishing scams by creating a fake payment page that uses this status code to make the request seem legitimate.

description: The request was a legal request but the server is refusing to respond to it
Possible_Threat: Continuous 403 responses could suggest an attacker is probing restricted areas of a site or application.

description: The requested page could not be found but may be available again in the future
Possible_Threat: High volume of 404 errors could indicate a reconnaissance attempt to discover unprotected files or outdated vulnerable scripts.

description: A request was made of a page using a request method not supported by that page
The server can only generate a response that is not accepted by the client
The client must first authenticate itself with the proxy
Possible_Threat: Attackers might attempt to steal credentials by setting up a malicious proxy that requires authentication (triggering a 407 response) and then logging the credentials that users input.

description: The server timed out waiting for the request
Possible_Threat: Attackers might deliberately send incomplete requests or flood the server with connections that never complete causing the server to timeout these requests. This could overwhelm the server making it unavailable to legitimate users.

description: The request could not be completed because of a conflict in the request
Possible_Threat: Attackers may attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in web applications that cause conflicts. For example exploiting race conditions improper data handling or concurrency issues might result in a 409 Conflict error.

description: The requested page is no longer available
Possible_Threat: Attackers may intentionally remove phishing sites / malicious files or other harmful content to evade detection after their initial use.

description: The Content-Length is not defined. The server will not accept the request without it
Possible_Threat: Attackers may send incomplete or malformed requests to probe the server's behavior potentially as a precursor to more targeted attacks like SQL injection or command injection.

description: The precondition given in the request evaluated to false by the server
The server will not accept the request because the request entity is too large
The server will not accept the request because the URI is too long. Occurs when you convert a POST request to a GET request with a long query information
The server will not accept the request because the media type is not supported
The client has asked for a portion of the file but the server cannot supply that portion
The server cannot meet the requirements of the Expect request-header field
A generic error message given when no more specific message is suitable
Possible_Threat: Persistent 500 errors may indicate that an attacker is trying to exploit server-side vulnerabilities like SQL injection or buffer overflows.

description: The server either does not recognize the request method or it lacks the ability to fulfill the request
The server was acting as a gateway or proxy and received an invalid response from the upstream server
Possible_Threat: Could indicate misconfiguration or even be a sign of an ongoing attack such as a DoS attack against an upstream server.

description: The server is currently unavailable (overloaded or down)
Possible_Threat: Often linked to server overloads. Repeated instances might point to a DoS or DDoS attack. It could also indicate an attacker attempting to take a service offline.

description: The server was acting as a gateway or proxy and did not receive a timely response from the upstream server
Possible_Threat: This can signal network latency issues or that an attacker is deliberately trying to cause slowdowns in the communication between systems.

description: The server does not support the HTTP protocol version used in the request
Possible_Threat: May be used by attackers to test server configurations and behavior with unsupported or deprecated HTTP versions.

description: The client needs to authenticate to gain network access
